citations.narrative:
On May 24, 2021, during a contracted animal interaction at the facility, a guest was bitten on the left upper arm by a lion
cub. The guest reported that immediately after biting, the cub was apparently scared/apprehensive from any additional
interaction. During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the
public, with sufficient safeguards as to assure the safety of animals and the public. When interacting with guests, the
handling of animals by trained facility personnel must be done as safely/carefully and expeditiously as possible in a
manner that does not cause physical harm neither to the animal or the public.
Corrected by the time of this inspection.

On September 20, 2022, a guest/patron of the facility posted several videos and photographs on social media (Facebook)
of interactions with an adult clouded leopard with no apparent animal handler controlling the animal. Also, on May 7,
2022, a guest posted on social media (Facebook) photos of a patron too close to the actual enclosure fence of adult
tigers; no safety barrier was visible. Furthermore, photos and a video show the same patron with the hand against the
tigers' enclosure fence. To prevent possible injuries/attacks to the public and the welfare of animals during public
exhibition, procedures to honor safety barriers must be in place, and dangerous animals such as lions, tigers, leopards,
bears, and/or others must always be under the direct control and supervision of a knowledgeable and experienced animal
handler.
Corrected by the time of this inspection.

The outside of most plastic nesting boxes at enclosures in the capuchin breeder’s section were found to be partially
soiled/dirty and in need of immediate cleaning. The surfaces within nonhuman primate enclosures (NHP) - including
perches, shelves, swings, boxes, houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures or objects – must be readily cleaned and
sanitized, or removed or replaced when worn or soiled. Hard surfaces with which NHP come in contact must be cleaned
daily and sanitized in accordance with generally accepted professional and husbandry practices to prevent accumulation
of excreta or disease hazards. To ensure the welfare and prevention of health hazards of all NHP in the capuchin
breeder’s section, all plastic nesting boxes should be cleaned and sanitized on a daily basis.
Correct by: February 16, 2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The space between the perimeter fence’s eastern section and the closest panel of the chimpanzee’s primary enclosure
was observed with excessive vegetation and debris. The facility must keep its premises free of accumulations of trash,
junk, waste, discarded matter and/or overgrown vegetation. To conduct appropriate pest control and to ensure the
integrity of the perimeter fence, the facility must clear any accumulation of debris and overgrown vegetation near the
perimeter fence and around the chimpanzee’s primary enclosure.
Correct by: March 1, 2023

Several wood planks and plywood boards at the jaguar’s enclosure were observed to be extremely damaged/rotted.
Many sharp wood splinters/points were present in the affected areas which are injury hazards for the animals. Also, two
large holes were identified by the main entrance gate of the African crested porcupines’ enclosure; both porcupines in the
enclosure were observed during this inspection digging the same holes/area. Housing facilities for all regulated animals
shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury while containing the
animals. To prevent potential injuries to the animals, the wood planks and plywood boards at the jaguar’s enclosure must
be repaired/replaced. Furthermore, to prevent the escape of an animal, the holes by the main gate of the African crested
porcupine should be reinforced/repaired.
Correct by: March 1, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with two facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On May 24, 2021, during a contracted animal interaction at the facility, a guest was bitten on the left upper arm by a lion 
cub.  The guest reported that immediately after biting, the cub was apparently scared/apprehensive from any additional 
interaction.  During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the 
public, with sufficient safeguards as to assure the safety of animals and the public.  When interacting with guests, the 
handling of animals by trained facility personnel must be done as safely/carefully and expeditiously as possible in a 
manner that does not cause physical harm neither to the animal or the public. 
 
Corrected by the time of this inspection. 
2.131(d)(3)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On September 20, 2022, a guest/patron of the facility posted several videos and photographs on social media (Facebook) 
of interactions with an adult clouded leopard with no apparent animal handler controlling the animal.  Also, on May 7, 
2022, a guest posted on social media (Facebook) photos of a patron too close to the actual enclosure fence of adult 
tigers; no safety barrier was visible.  Furthermore, photos and a video show the same patron with the hand against the

tigers' enclosure fence.  To prevent possible injuries/attacks to the public and the welfare of animals during public 
exhibition, procedures to honor safety barriers must be in place, and dangerous animals such as lions, tigers, leopards, 
bears, and/or others must always be under the direct control and supervision of a knowledgeable and experienced animal 
handler. 
 
Corrected by the time of this inspection. 
3.75(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The outside of most plastic nesting boxes at enclosures in the capuchin breeder’s section were found to be partially 
soiled/dirty and in need of immediate cleaning.  The surfaces within nonhuman primate enclosures (NHP) - including 
perches, shelves, swings, boxes, houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures or objects – must be readily cleaned and 
sanitized, or removed or replaced when worn or soiled.  Hard surfaces with which NHP come in contact must be cleaned 
daily and sanitized in accordance with generally accepted professional and husbandry practices to prevent accumulation 
of excreta or disease hazards.  To ensure the welfare and prevention of health hazards of all NHP in the capuchin 
breeder’s section, all plastic nesting boxes should be cleaned and sanitized on a daily basis. 
 
Correct by: February 16, 2023 
3.84(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The space between the perimeter fence’s eastern section and the closest panel of the chimpanzee’s primary enclosure 
was observed with excessive vegetation and debris. The facility must keep its premises free of accumulations of trash, 
junk, waste, discarded matter and/or overgrown vegetation.   To conduct appropriate pest control and to ensure the

integrity of the perimeter fence, the facility must clear any accumulation of debris and overgrown vegetation near the 
perimeter fence and around the chimpanzee’s primary enclosure. 
 
Correct by: March 1, 2023 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Several wood planks and plywood boards at the jaguar’s enclosure were observed to be extremely damaged/rotted.  
Many sharp wood splinters/points were present in the affected areas which are injury hazards for the animals.  Also, two 
large holes were identified by the main entrance gate of the African crested porcupines’ enclosure; both porcupines in the 
enclosure were observed during this inspection digging the same holes/area.  Housing facilities for all regulated animals 
shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury while containing the 
animals.  To prevent potential injuries to the animals, the wood planks and plywood boards at the jaguar’s enclosure must 
be repaired/replaced.  Furthermore, to prevent the escape of an animal, the holes by the main gate of the African crested 
porcupine should be reinforced/repaired. 
 
Correct by: March 1, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with two facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
